explanation: The first law states that for any closed system the change in internal energy `Delta U` equals heat supplied `Q` minus work done `W`. It enforces macroscopic energy conservation without specifying microscopic details, underpinning calorimetry, engine-cycle analysis and phase-transition studies. Engineers apply it to compute energy balances, determine heating requirements and set upper limits on process efficiency.

assumptions: System mass remains constant; no matter crosses the boundary.
Positive `Q` denotes heat added to the system, while positive `W` denotes work done by the system.
Mechanical work is limited to quasi-static `p*V` expansion/compression at the system boundary.
Closed system: no mass crosses the boundary during the process.
Macroscopic kinetic energy change is negligible, so `dE_kin = 0`.
Macroscopic potential energy change is negligible, so `dE_pot = 0`.

derivation.description: Apply conservation of energy to a closed system: any change in total energy equals energy added as heat minus energy lost as work.
Resolve total energy into internal, kinetic and potential contributions.
Differentiate to relate infinitesimal changes of the individual energy modes.
Assume the centre-of-mass velocity is constant, eliminating kinetic energy changes.
Assume the system's elevation in a gravitational field is unchanged, eliminating potential energy changes.
Substitute the previous two results into the energy balance to isolate the differential change in internal energy.
Integrate the differential relation between two equilibrium states to obtain the finite difference form.
